title: 107_hr1275
content: Credit for certain energy-efficient property. Credit for certain energy-efficient property. Business Property. Amended definition of energy property to include energy-efficient building property. Energy-efficient building property defined as stationary fuel cell power. The amended definition of energy property now includes energy-efficient building property, defined as a stationary fuel cell power plant with high electricity generation efficiency. The credit for such property is limited to $1,000 per kilowatt of capacity. The definition of energy property now includes energy-efficient building property, such as stationary fuel cell power plants with high electricity generation efficiency. The amendments made by this subsection apply to property placed in service after December 31, 2001. "Nonbusiness energy-efficient building property falls under the definition of energy property, including stationary fuel cell power plants with high electricity generation efficiency. These amendments apply to property placed in service after December 31, 2001." For an individual, a tax credit is allowed for nonbusiness energy-efficient building property expenditures paid or incurred during the taxable year. This includes expenditures for property installed on a dwelling unit used by the taxpayer as a residence in the United States. Labor costs for onsite preparation, assembly, or installation are also included. Tax credit available for nonbusiness energy-efficient building property expenditures for individuals, including labor costs for installation on a dwelling unit used as a residence in the United States. Special rules apply for tenant-stockholders in cooperative housing corporations. Individuals who are members of a condominium management association owning a condominium are treated as having made their share of association expenditures. The association must meet specific requirements related to condominium projects used primarily as residences. Individuals who are members of a condominium management association owning a condominium are treated as having made their share of association expenditures, the units of which are used as residences. Expenditures for items used for nonbusiness purposes must be properly allocated. Expenditures for items are considered made upon completion of the original installation, except for expenditures in connection with building construction. For nonbusiness energy-efficient building property expenditures, the cost of any expenditure shall be the amount treated as made when the taxpayer begins using the structure. Expenditures from subsidized energy financing are not considered. Basis adjustments reduce the property's basis increase resulting from the expenditure if a credit is allowed. The section applies to expenditures made before December 31, 2006, and includes amendments to the Internal Revenue Code related to the credit allowed under section 25B. The new item is inserted after section 25A, related to amendments to the Internal Revenue Code for the credit under section 25B. Section 25B introduces nonbusiness energy-efficient building property with amendments effective for expenditures after December 31, 2001.
